source: BIR Form 2550Q — Quarterly VAT Return Detailed Guide

chunks.title: Who Must File BIR Form 2550Q and Filing Deadline
chunks.content: BIR Form 2550Q (Quarterly Value-Added Tax Return) must be filed by every VAT-registered person or entity, including corporations, partnerships, cooperatives, associations, individuals engaged in trade or business, and any person required to register for VAT under Section 236 of the NIRC. This includes those whose gross annual sales or receipts exceed PHP 3,000,000 (the VAT threshold). The quarterly return must be filed and the tax paid on or before the 25th day following the close of each taxable quarter. The taxable quarters are: Q1 (January–March, due April 25), Q2 (April–June, due July 25), Q3 (July–September, due October 25), and Q4 (October–December, due January 25 of the following year). Filing is done electronically via eFPS (for large taxpayers and top withholding agents) or eBIRForms. Manual filing is only permitted where electronic filing infrastructure is unavailable. Late filing is subject to a 25% surcharge, 12% interest per annum (as amended by TRAIN Law), and a compromise penalty under RMO 7-2015.

chunks.title: Part I — Background Information and Taxpayer Details
chunks.content: Part I of BIR Form 2550Q captures the taxpayer's background information. This includes: TIN (Taxpayer Identification Number) with branch code, RDO (Revenue District Office) code, taxpayer name (for individuals: last name, first name, middle name; for non-individuals: registered name), registered address, ZIP code, contact number, email address, taxpayer type (single proprietor, corporation, partnership, etc.), and the applicable taxable quarter and year. The taxpayer must indicate whether this is an original filing or an amended return. If amended, the date of the original filing and the amended return number must be stated. The ATC (Alphanumeric Tax Code) for regular quarterly VAT is VT010 (for VAT on sales of goods) or VT020 (for VAT on sales of services). The taxpayer must also declare whether they have any transactions with related parties within the quarter. Accurate Part I details are essential because errors in TIN or RDO code can lead to misposting of payments and trigger BIR compliance notices.

chunks.title: Part II — Domestic Purchases, Importations, and Zero-Rated Purchases (Input Side Detail)
chunks.content: Part II of 2550Q details the taxpayer's purchases and importations broken down into several categories. Section A covers Domestic Purchases of Goods other than Capital Goods: list gross purchase amount and the 12% input VAT. Section B covers Domestic Purchases of Services: similarly, gross amount and 12% input VAT. Section C covers Importation of Goods other than Capital Goods: customs duty-inclusive landed cost and VAT paid to Customs. Section D covers Domestic Purchases of Capital Goods: purchases of depreciable assets exceeding PHP 1,000,000 — input VAT on these is amortized over 60 months or the useful life of the asset, whichever is shorter. If below PHP 1,000,000, input VAT is claimed in full in the quarter of purchase. Section E covers Services Rendered by Non-Residents: reverse charge VAT — the local buyer withholds and remits 12% VAT on behalf of the non-resident, then claims the same as input VAT. Purchases from VAT-exempt persons or non-VAT registered entities do not generate creditable input tax and should not be included. All purchases must be supported by valid VAT official receipts or invoices with the seller's TIN, and entries must match the Summary List of Purchases (SLP).

chunks.title: Part III — Output Tax Computation (Sales and Receipts)
chunks.content: Part III computes the output VAT liability. Line items include: (1) Taxable Sales/Receipts (Vatable Sales) — the total amount of sales of goods, properties, or services subject to 12% VAT, multiplied by 12% to get output tax; (2) Zero-Rated Sales — export sales under Section 106(A)(2) and Section 108(B) of the NIRC, sales to PEZA/ecozone enterprises (reinstated under CREATE MORE), sales to diplomatic missions, and other zero-rated transactions — these are reported at gross amount but carry 0% output tax; (3) Exempt Sales — sales of agricultural food products, educational services, residential dwelling below PHP 3,199,200 threshold (adjusted annually), health services, and other items under Section 109 of the NIRC — reported for informational purposes but no output tax is charged; (4) Government Sales — sales to government agencies where VAT is withheld at 5% final withholding VAT (under RR 4-2007, now 12% starting 2025 per EOPT Act amendments — but the 5% final VAT has been repealed for certain transactions; consult latest RRs). The output tax total is the sum of all output VAT on vatable sales. Proper classification is critical because misclassifying exempt sales as zero-rated (or vice versa) affects the input tax apportionment calculation.

chunks.title: Part IV — Input Tax Computation and Carry-Over from Previous Quarter
chunks.content: Part IV computes total creditable input tax. The components are: (1) Input Tax Carried Over from Previous Quarter — the excess input tax from the prior quarter's 2550Q, which can be carried forward indefinitely (but once carried over, cannot be refunded under Section 112, only current quarter excess input on zero-rated sales is refundable); (2) Input Tax on Domestic Purchases of Goods — from Part II Section A; (3) Input Tax on Domestic Purchases of Services — from Part II Section B; (4) Input Tax on Importations — from Part II Section C; (5) Input Tax on Capital Goods (current amortization) — from Part II Section D; (6) Transitional Input Tax (Section 111) — 2% of beginning inventory value when first becoming VAT-registered, claimable only once; (7) Presumptive Input Tax (Section 111(B)) — 4% of gross value for specific industries (sardines, milk, cooking oil, refined sugar, noodles); (8) Deferred Input Tax on Capital Goods — the portion of amortized input tax claimable this quarter. For mixed transactions (taxable + exempt), input tax must be apportioned using the ratable allocation formula: Creditable Input Tax = Total Input Tax × (Taxable Sales including Zero-Rated) / Total Sales. This allocation must be finalized at year-end using actual annual figures, with any quarterly estimated allocation adjusted in Q4.

chunks.title: Part V — Tax Credits, Payments, and Net VAT Payable
chunks.content: Part V determines the net VAT payable or excess input tax. The computation is: Output Tax (Part III) minus Total Input Tax (Part IV) = Net VAT Payable or Excess Input Tax. If net VAT is payable, the taxpayer must deduct: (1) Tax Credits from prior quarter's 2550M (monthly VAT already paid for the first two months of the quarter — these are creditable against the quarterly VAT); (2) Tax Credits/Payments under BIR Form 2307 — creditable withholding VAT certificates received from government agencies or large taxpayers who withheld VAT on purchases; (3) Advance VAT Payments, if any. The final amount due is the remaining balance after all credits. If total input tax exceeds output tax, the excess is carried over to the next quarter via the 2550Q. Alternatively, for zero-rated or effectively zero-rated sellers, the excess may be claimed as a refund or tax credit certificate (TCC) under Section 112. The taxpayer must declare under penalties of perjury that the return is true and correct. Payment must be made through Authorized Agent Banks (AABs), eFPS, or GCash/PayMaya for amounts below PHP 20,000.

chunks.title: Required Attachments: SLS, SLP, SAWT, and Schedules
chunks.content: Several attachments must accompany the 2550Q filing: (1) Summary List of Sales (SLS) — a detailed listing of all sales transactions for the quarter, showing the buyer's TIN, name, address, amount of sale, and output VAT. For zero-rated sales, the legal basis for zero-rating must be indicated. (2) Summary List of Purchases (SLP) — a detailed listing of all purchase transactions, showing the seller's TIN, name, address, amount of purchase, and input VAT claimed. (3) Summary Alphalist of Withholding Taxes (SAWT) — listing of all taxes withheld by or from the taxpayer during the quarter, cross-referenced with BIR Forms 2307 received and issued. (4) Schedule of Exempt Sales — if the taxpayer has mixed transactions, a schedule showing the breakdown of exempt sales by category under Section 109. (5) Schedule of Capital Goods Amortization — for capital goods with input VAT being amortized over 60 months. (6) MAP (Monthly Alphalist of Payees) if applicable. All attachments must be submitted electronically via the BIR eSubmission facility (esubmission@bir.gov.ph) or through the Online Registration and Update System (ORUS). The SLS and SLP must use the BIR-prescribed CSV format (per RMC 57-2015). Failure to submit attachments is penalized separately and may trigger an audit.

chunks.title: Common Errors and Frequently Asked Questions
chunks.content: Common errors in filing 2550Q include: (1) Double-counting input VAT already claimed in 2550M — the quarterly return should only show the net quarterly computation, not re-add monthly inputs; (2) Failure to apportion input tax for mixed transactions — taxpayers with both taxable and exempt sales must use the ratable allocation formula; (3) Claiming input VAT on purchases without valid VAT invoices or receipts — the invoice must show the seller's TIN and VAT registration, and must state 'VAT' explicitly; (4) Not carrying over excess input tax from the prior quarter — this must be manually entered and must match the prior 2550Q; (5) Incorrect ATC codes leading to misposted payments; (6) Claiming input VAT on personal expenses or non-business-related purchases; (7) Not filing zero-rated sales schedules, which can void zero-rated status on audit. FAQ: Q: Can I amend 2550Q after filing? A: Yes, within 3 years from filing deadline, but amended returns may trigger audit. Q: What if I have no sales this quarter? A: You must still file a 'nil' return. Q: Can I offset VAT payable against income tax? A: No, VAT is an indirect tax and cannot be offset against income tax liabilities.

chunks.title: Relationship Between BIR Form 2550M and 2550Q
chunks.content: The Monthly VAT Declaration (BIR Form 2550M) and the Quarterly VAT Return (BIR Form 2550Q) work together as follows: For each quarter, the taxpayer files 2550M for the first two months and 2550Q for the entire quarter (covering all three months). Example for Q1: 2550M is filed for January (due February 20) and February (due March 20), while 2550Q covers January through March combined (due April 25). The 2550Q is the 'summary and settlement' return. The VAT payments made via the 2550M for months 1 and 2 are credited against the quarterly VAT liability in the 2550Q. Thus, the net amount due on the 2550Q is: Total Quarterly Output Tax minus Total Quarterly Input Tax minus Monthly VAT Payments Already Made (from 2550M for months 1 and 2). If the monthly payments exceed the quarterly liability, the excess is carried forward. It is important that the 2550M figures are consistent with the 2550Q — any discrepancy will be flagged by the BIR's Integrated Tax System (ITS). Starting 2023, the BIR enhanced cross-matching between 2550M and 2550Q filings to detect under-declaration.

chunks.title: Amended Quarterly VAT Return Filing Rules
chunks.content: An amended 2550Q may be filed to correct errors or reflect adjustments. Under Section 6(A) of the NIRC and RR 2-2006, a taxpayer may amend a return within three (3) years from the date of filing or the statutory deadline, whichever is later. Rules for amended returns: (1) The amended return must indicate 'Amended' in Part I and reference the original filing date and confirmation number; (2) If the amendment results in additional VAT payable, the taxpayer must pay the deficiency plus applicable surcharges and interest from the original due date; (3) If the amendment results in a decrease in tax due (overpayment), the taxpayer may either carry forward the excess or apply for a refund/TCC, subject to Section 229 (2-year prescriptive period for refund claims); (4) Filing an amended return may trigger a BIR investigation under Section 235, particularly if the amendment significantly reduces the tax liability; (5) Under the EOPT Act (RA 11976), amended returns filed within the 3-year period are generally allowed without penalty provided any additional tax is paid voluntarily. However, if an amendment is filed after a Letter of Authority (LOA) or audit notice has been issued, it will not stop or prevent the audit. Best practice is to file amendments as early as possible and maintain documentation supporting the reasons for amendment.
